Graphical abstract Fig. (a, b) CVs of Pt/(Ti3C2T x ) y -(MWCNTs)1- y catalysts in 1 M H2SO4 solution scanned at 20 mV/s, (c) comparison of the corresponding ECSA values for those catalysts of (a, b). (d, e) CVs of Pt/(Ti3C2T x ) y -(MWCNTs)1- y catalysts in a mixed solution of 1 M H2SO4 and 2 M CH3OH solution scanned at 20 mV/s, (f) the forward peak current normalized to the ECSA value (specific activity) and Pt mass (mass activity), respectively (insert shows the schematic of the electrocatalytic methanol oxidation mechanism). Although direct methanol fuel cells are promising as “green” power generators for portable electronics, their further development has been largely hampered by the low-efficiency of the commercial anode catalysts. In this study, (Ti3C2T x ) y -(MWCNTs)1- y (0 ≤ y ≤1) supported Pt nanoparticle electrocatalysts were fabricated by a facile and scalable solvothermal strategy, after which two-dimensional(2D) Ti3C2T x nanosheets were found to be intercalated and connected by conductive one-dimensional(1D) MWCNTs. Used for methanol oxidation reaction, the Pt/(Ti3C2T x )0.5-(MWCNTs)0.5 catalyst exhibited the maximum electrochemical active surface area (ECSA, 154 m2/g) and excellent electrochemical activity (812.9 mA/mg), higher than not only Pt/Ti3C2T x and Pt/MWCNTs of this study, but also many other related catalysts reported in literature. In addition, the CO-poisoning behavior was also alleviated using Pt/(Ti3C2T x )0.5-(MWCNTs)0.5 instead of Pt/Ti3C2T x and Pt/MWCNTs. Such a superior performance can be attributed to the well dispersion of Pt nanoparticles (∼3.8 nm), enhanced layer distance of Ti3C2T x to capture more Pt nanoparticles, and conductive action of MWCNTs to connect Ti3C2T x . This study opens a new perspective for developing high performance supercapacitors using Pt catalysts supported by 1D-intercalated 2D materials. Keywords Ti3C2Tx Multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) Pt catalysts Direct methanol fuel cells Methanol oxidation Electrochemical activity 1 Introduction The dependence of human society on energy is increasing due to the rapid industrialization and social development, whereas the new clean energy candidates have been highly expected due to the gradual depletion of fossil fuels as well as rapid environmental deterioration [1]. In recent years, direct methanol fuel cells (DMFCs) are attracting much more attention due to the merits of high energy conversion efficiency and low pollution emission [2,3]. Although platinum has been regarded as a competitive anode electrocatalyst for DMFCs, its wide commercialization for the fuel cell system has been hindered greatly by the shortcomings of slow kinetics of oxygen reduction reaction and poor long term stability. In order to conquer these issues, the dispersion of Pt nanoparticles on appropriate support materials, such as graphene [4–7] carbon black [8], carbon fiber [9], porous carbon [10] and carbon nanotubes (CNTs) [11], are also possible candidates to support Pt nanoparticles. In particular, one-dimensional (1D) CNTs are highly desired for DMFCs due to its high aspect ratio, large surface area, good chemical stability and exceptional electrical conductivity [12–14]. But easily bending and entangling phenomena with each other are the defects of CNTs need to be conquered. Since 2011, a new family of two-dimensional (2D) early transition metal carbide and/or carbonitrides, labeled “MXenes”, have been obtained by selectively etching “A” layers from the MAX phases [15,16]. The invented MXenes in literatures include Ti2C [17], Ti3C2 [18], Ti3CN [19], Nb2C [20], TiNbC [21], TaC2 [22], V2C [23], etc., among which Ti3C2, also known as Ti3C2T x (T x represents the existent of surface functional groups OH− and F−), has been most intensively studied [24]. Due to their unique structure, excellent physical and chemical properties, MXenes are promising for applications in metal ion batteries [25], supercapacitors [26], hydrogen storage [27], adsorption [28–30]. However, after being immersed in an aqueous solution, the layer agglomeration and functional groups especially was found to decrease the specific surface area and conductivity of the prepared MXenes [31], which has hindered the real applications of MXenes for DMFCs, herein, CNTs could be introduced to increase interlayer space, and provide better electronic transport capacity. In this study, we propose a simple but easy-operative approach to fabricate Pt/(Ti3C2T x ) y -(MWCNTs)1- y (0 ≤ y ≤1) electrocatalysts for DMFCs. As illustrated in Fig. 1 , Ti3C2T x was synthesized by etching “Al” atom layer from Ti3AlC2 with HF. Simultaneously, MWCNTs (multi-walled CNTs) were pretreated by acid solution to increase the affinity with Ti3C2T x through oxygen-containing functional groups. Then Ti3C2T x , MWCNTs, and K2PtCl4 were mixed and reacted in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave to obtain the final Pt/(Ti3C2T x ) y -(MWCNTs)1- y electrocatalysts. Such a processing increased the electrocatalytic surface area and activity toward methanol oxidation, which can be attributed to the modified microstructure and synergic effects. Compared with Pt/Ti3C2T x and Pt/MWCNTs, the triplet Pt/(Ti3C2T x ) y -(MWCNTs)1- y exhibit higher catalytic activity and better electrochemical stability. 2 Experimental procedure 2.1 Raw materials The MAX Ti3AlC2 powder (purity > 99%) was purchased from Forsman Corporation in Beijing of China, and passed through a 400-mesh sieve before use. The multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs, 10–30 μm in length, SSA > 150 m2/g) were purchased from Chengdu Institute of Organic Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Hydrofluoric acid (HF, 40 wt.%) was obtained from Aladdin Reagent Corporation in Shanghai of China. Nafion solution (5%, Dupont) and commercial K2PtCl4 were obtained from Alfa Aesar Corporation in Shanghai of China, and used as obtained. 2.2 Pre-treatment of MXene Ti3C2Tx and MWCNTs Ti3AlC2 powder, 1 g in weight, was immersed in 20 mL 40% HF solution at room temperature, and oscillated for 48 h. The obtained suspension was washed several times with deionized water until the pH value became ∼7, and dried in a vacuum oven at 80 °C for 12 h. Thereafter, the dried Ti3C2T x was obtained and placed in a capped glass vial and stored in inert atmosphere. MWCNTs powders (0.1 g) were first treated with 100 mL concentrated acid solution (H2SO4:HNO3 = 3:1). The mixed solution was ultrasonicated and continuously stirred at 50 °C for 3 h. After that, the solution was diluted with deionized water for three times. Upon cooling, the black suspension was washed with deionized water until the pH value of supernatant reached near neutral. Then the MWCNTs were dried at 100 °C for 24 h for further use. 2.3 Preparation of Pt/(Ti3C2T x ) y -(MWCNTs)1- y catalysts The typical synthesis procedure of Pt/(Ti3C2T x ) y -(MWCNTs)1- y catalysts is shown as follows. Firstly, Ti3C2T x and MWCNTs powders were ultrasonically dispersed in a solution of 40 mL ethylene glycol and 40 mL deionized water for 1 h. Then an appropriate amount of K2PtCl4 was put into the above solution and magnetically stirred for 15 min. After that, the mixed solution was moved into a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and well sealed. After heating the autoclave at 120 °C for 18 h, the final products of Pt/(Ti3C2T x ) y -(MWCNTs)1- y catalysts were washed with deionized water three times and dried in a vacuum oven at 80 °C for 12 h. By adjusting the y value, various catalysts of Pt/Ti3C2T x , Pt/(Ti3C2T x )0.7-(MWCNTs)0.3, Pt/(Ti3C2T x )0.5-(MWCNTs)0.5, Pt/(Ti3C2T x )0.3-(MWCNTs)0.7 and Pt/MWCNTs were obtained by repeating the above procedure. And the actual loadings of Pt in Pt/Ti3C2T x , Pt/(Ti3C2T x )0.7-(MWCNTs)0.3, Pt/(Ti3C2T x )0.5-(MWCNTs)0.5, Pt/(Ti3C2T x )0.3-(MWCNTs)0.7 and Pt/MWCNTs catalyst, measured by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES, Agilent 730), were 16.9, 16.2, 17.6, 15.5 and 14.6 wt%, respectively. 2.4 Microstructures The phase composition of the samples was identified by X-ray diffraction patterns apparatus (XRD, Bruker D8 Advance, CuKα, Germany). The morphology was observed by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM, Hitachi S-4800, Japan) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM, JEOL JEM-2100, Japan). The elemental composition was characterized by energy dispersive spectrum (EDS, Bruker AXS, Quantax 400-30, Germany). The electronic structure of Ti, C and Pt atoms was evaluated by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo ESCALAB 250, USA). FT-IR spectra were measured by a Fourier infrared spectroscopy (Bruker Tensor27, Germany) via the KBr tablet method. Raman spectroscopy was performed using a LabRAM Aramis Raman Microprobe (Horiba Jobin Yvon S.A.S, France) with a 532 nm laser excitation line. 2.5 Electrocatalytic performance The electrochemical measurement was executed by a CHI 760E electrochemical workstation with a standard three-electrode configuration, for which Pt wire was employed as the counter electrode, saturated calomel as the reference electrode, and the catalysts coated glassy carbon (GC) with the diameter of 3 mm as the working electrode, respectively. The working electrode was manufactured as follows: 2 mg catalyst was dispersed in a mixed solution of 500 μL water, 500 μL ethanol and 50 μL 5 wt.% Nafio solution, and sonicated for 30 min. Afterwards, 5 μL catalyst ink was pipetted onto the GC electrode surface, and dried naturally. The electrochemical activation test was conducted by cyclic voltammetry (CV) in 1 M H2SO4 solution under the potential range from −0.2 V to 1.2 V until the CV curve reached to be stable. To determine electrochemical surface area (ECSA), hydrogen adsorption/desorption (Hads/Hdes) process was performed by using CV from −0.2 to 1 V at scan rate of 20 mV/s in 1 M H2SO4. ECSA was calculated from the ratio of coulombic charge from hydrogen adsorption/desorption process to mass loading of Pt on the working electrode. The electrocatalytic activity of the catalyst was evaluated by cyclic voltammetry (CV) at a scan rate of 20 mV/s from 0 to 1 V in 1 M H2SO4 and 2 M CH3OH solution. The electrochemical stability was evaluated in a potential range from 0 to 1 V in a mixed solution of 1 M H2SO4 and 2 M CH3OH for 1000 cycles at 20 mV/s. The chronopotentiometry (CA) curves were measured at a constant potential of 0.5 V for 2000s. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 2 displays the typical XRD patterns of (a) the as-prepared Ti3AlC2, Ti3C2T x and (b) Pt/Ti3C2T x -MWCNTs composites. After etching Ti3AlC2 by HF, the typical (104) peak of Ti3AlC2 2θ ≈ 39°disappeared, confirming the removal of Al layers from Ti3AlC2 to form Ti3C2T x as expected. In addition, the 2θ position of (002) peak shifted from 9.5°to 8.8° due to the structural expansion by substitution of Al with F−, OH−, and O2− terminal groups [32]. On the other hand, Fig. 2(b) shows that the peaks of Pt, Ti3C2T x , and MWCNTs were identified in the XRD patterns, suggesting that the three components were successfully compounded together. Fig. 3 (a) shows the Raman spectrum recorded for Ti3AlC2, Ti3C2T x , MWCNTs, Pt/MWCNTs and Pt/(Ti3C2T x )0.5-(MWCNTs)0.5 hybrids. The typical peaks peak between 260 and 1000 cm−1 of Ti3AlC2 almost vanished after the etching treatment, and a typical peak at ∼150 cm−1 observed was ascribed to the formation of Ti3C2T x . In addition, the D-band at ∼1340 cm−1 and G-band at 1570 cm−1, associated with the disorder degree and the edge defects of the graphite structure, are both observed in MWCNTs, Pt/MWCNTs, and Pt/(Ti3C2T x )0.5-(MWCNTs)0.5 composites [33]. Accordingly, I D/I G was calculated and shown in Fig. 3(b). Through solvothermal reaction process, surface functional group of MWCNTs reduced, ID /IG of Pt/MWCNTs drop to 0.90 from 1.49. Meanwhile, compared with Pt/MWCNTs (0.90), a higher I D/I G ratio (1.28) was obtained in Pt/(Ti3C2T x )0.5-(MWCNTs)0.5 composite, revealed the disorder state owing to the hybrids of Ti3C2Tx-MWCNTs. As shown in Fig. 4 (a–c) and Fig. 4(d–f), the microstructure of the as-prepared samples was further examined by FESEM and HRTEM, respectively. A typical multilayered accordion-like morphology of Ti3C2T x is clearly visible, validating the successful etching of Al element layers form Ti3AlC2 phases by HF acid (Fig. 4(b) and (d). Interestingly, MWCNTs were observed to not only distribute on the surface, but also in the interlayer of Ti3C2T x , which could only act as a conductive “bridge” to connect Ti3C2T x , but also prevent the interlayer aggregation of the etched layers of Ti3C2T x. As shown in Fig. 4(e)–(h), Pt nanoparticles were dispersed uniformly on MWCNTs and Ti3C2T x support after the hydrothermal reaction. In addition, the average Pt nanoparticles size for Pt/(Ti3C2T x )0.5-(MWCNTs)0.5 (3.9 nm, Fig. 4(f)) are smaller than that for Pt/Ti3C2T x (4.5 nm, Fig. 4(g)) and Pt/MWCNTs (5.2 nm, Fig. 4(h)), the high dispersion of Pt NPs is essential to the electrocatalytic activity of the composites for methanol oxidation. In order to characterize the interaction among the three components of Pt, Ti3C2T x and MWCNTs, their X-Ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were examined as shown in Fig. 5 . Five characteristic peaks are found located at a binding energy of 71.4, 284.8, 330.1, 459.3, 532.5, and 685.4 eV, ascribed to the Pt4f, C1s, Pt4d, Ti2p, O1s and F1s, respectively, and the atomic ratio of Pt, O, C, Ti were shown in Fig. 5(a–c). The C1s spectrum of Pt/Ti3C2T x , Pt/(Ti3C2T x )0.5-(MWCNTs)0.5, and Pt/MWCNTs was shown in Fig. 4(d–f), including sp2 CC (284.7 eV), COH (286.2 eV), COC (287.7 eV), OCOH (288.9 eV) and CTi (282.0 eV) [34]. Compared with Pt/Ti3C2T x , the relative peak area of COH and OCOH in Pt/(Ti3C2T x )0.5-(MWCNTs)0.5 decreased obviously due to the incorporation of MWCNTs, indicating that the reduced state was improved after the hydrothermal reaction process. Fig. 4(g–i) present the Ti2p, O1s, Pt4f core-level XPS spectrum of Pt/(Ti3C2T x )0.5-(MWCNTs)0.5, respectively. The Ti2p spectrum at the binding energies of 455.3, 459.1, 461.4 and 464.9 eV was ascribed to sp2-hybridized TiC(2p3/2), TiO(2p3/2), TiC(2p1/2) and TiO(2p1/2) groups, respectively [35]. After the solvothermal reaction process, the numerous TiO exist in state of TiOH, demonstrating the interaction of Ti3C2T x and MWCNTs impaired the electron density of Ti atoms. In addition, there are three Pt chemical states identified in Fig. 4(f), including metallic Pt0 (with two lower energy split peaks located at 71.4 eV, 74.7 eV), Pt2+(with two split peaks located at higher energy of 72.0 eV, 76.0 eV) and Pt4+(with one peak at 72.9 eV), among which Pt0 (83.4%) occupies the main part, benefiting the electrical conductivity and electrocatalytic behavior the as-obtained catalysts. On the other hand, Fig. 6 shows the FTIR peak intensity of MWCNTs for OH and CO was increased after the acid treatment due to the slight oxidation of MWCNTs [36], which was also proposed to contribute to the successful anchoring of Pt nanoparticles by providing more functional groups. The electrochemical properties of Pt/(Ti3C2T x ) y -(MWCNTs)1- y were investigated under the experimental conditions as described in the experimental procedure. The typical CVs of typical catalysts in 1 M H2SO4 solution at 20 mV/s were shown in Fig. 7 (a, b), based on which the ECSA values were calculated as shown in Fig. 7(c). Obvious adsorption/desorption peaks of hydrogen on Pt were observed clearly under a potential range from −0.2 V to 0.1 V in the cathodic and anodic scan, respectively. Among the various Pt/(Ti3C2T x ) y -(MWCNTs)1- y catalysts, Pt/(Ti3C2T x )0.5-(MWCNTs)0.5 exhibited an ECSA value of 175 m2/g, much higher than that of Pt/Ti3C2T x (81 m2/g), Pt/(Ti3C2T x )0.3-(MWCNTs)0.7 (134 m2/g), Pt/(Ti3C2T x )0.7-(MWCNTs)0.3 (150 m2/g), Pt/MWCNTs (147 m2/g), indicating that compounding MWCNTs with Ti3C2T x is beneficial of expand the active sites of the catalysts effectively. The methanol oxidation performance of the Pt/(Ti3C2T x ) y -(MWCNTs)1- y catalysts was evaluated as shown in Fig. 7(d, e), based on which the anodic peak current density in the forward sweep were calculated as shown in Fig. 7(f). The schematic diagram of the electrocatalytic oxidation of methanol on Pt/(Ti3C2T x ) y -(MWCNTs)1- y in anodic scan was also exhibited insert of Fig. 7(f) and methanol electro-oxidation step of Pt-based catalyst was shown in step 3 below [37]: (1) Pt + CH3OH →  Pt-Coad  + 4H+ + 4e− (2) Pt + H2O  → Pt−OHad + H+ + e− (3) Pt−COad + Pt−OHad →  Pt + CO2 + H+ + e− In the process, the CO adsorbed on the Pt surface, which cause the toxic effect on the catalyst and suppresses the continuous methanol oxidation reaction, corresponding the peak around 0.5 V during reverse anodic scan, and current density was defined as Ir . And another peak occurring at around 0.7 V during forward anodic scan, standing for the oxidation of CH3OH, corresponding current density was defined as If . On the basis of the linear sweep voltammetry that electrodes behave at lower on-set potential (0.4–0.5 V), we can recognize that the potential of Pt/(Ti3C2T x )0.5-(MWCNTs)0.5 is remarkably lower than other proportions at a given oxidation current density, indicating that the catalysis processes take place more easily with the help of the Pt/(Ti3C2T x )0.5-(MWCNTs)0.5 catalyst. Moreover, the actual intrinsic activities of Pt/(Ti3C2T x ) y -(MWCNTs)1- y catalysts were assessed by normalizing the current density at 0.6˜0.8 V to the ECSA values (defined as “specific activity”) and the Pt mass (defined as “mass activity”), respectively. It is found that y = 0.5 is the best mass ratio to improve the electrocatalytic kinetics of methanol electro-oxidation. The ratio of If to Ir was employed to evaluate catalysts tolerance to the CO poisoning. The If /Ir value of Pt/Ti3C2T x , Pt/(Ti3C2T x )0.3-(MWCNTs)0.7, Pt/(Ti3C2T x )0.7-(MWCNTs)0.3, Pt/MWCNTs were 1.09, 1.13, 1.16, 1.08 and 1.19, respectively. Interestingly, the value of Pt/(Ti3C2T x ) y -(MWCNTs)1- y were similar, herein, to investigate the long-term stability, the chronoamperometry (CA) experiments were also carried out as shown in Fig. 8 (a) to of the Pt/(Ti3C2T x )0.5-(MWCNTs)0.5 at 0.5 V for 2000s in comparison with Pt/MWCNTs and Pt/Ti3C2T x . Compounding Ti3C2T x with MWCNTs as the support for Pt was found to slow the decay rate of the current density effectively compared to MWCNTs and Ti3C2T x , indicating a long-term stability was obtained for methanol oxidation. In addition, the durability of Pt NPs on various supporting materials were also evaluated by the continuous CV tests (Fig. 8(b)). It is impressive that the initial activity of Pt/(Ti3C2T x )0.5-(MWCNTs)0.5 decreased by 86.7% after 100 cycle times in acid solution, better than Pt/MWCNTs (96.4% loss) and Pt/Ti3C2T x (94.7% loss) catalysts. It further proves the better durability of the new sample Pt/(Ti3C2T x )0.5-(MWCNTs)0.5 toward on methanol oxidation. In order to further justify the act of MWCNTs, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was employed to assesses the conductivity of Pt/(Ti3C2T x ) y -(MWCNTs)1- y . As presented in Fig. 8(c, d), the conductivity increased as y goes down, the same thing is that more MWCNTs hybridized in Ti3C2T x , implying that within the addition of MWCNTs, Pt/(Ti3C2T x ) y -(MWCNTs)1- y provide faster electrochemical kinetics, larger populations of the triple-phase boundaries on Ti3C2T x based electrode surfaces, and MWCNT play a role of conductive “bridge”. The ECSA and If comparison of the Pt/(Ti3C2T x )0.5-(MWCNTs)0.5 catalyst with those of the recent state-of-the-art Pt-based electrocatalysts was also conducted as shown in Fig. 9 and Table 1 [38–52], suggesting the preeminent performance of this study. The above analysis has validated that Pt nanoparticles supported by Ti3C2T x -MWCNTs exhibit excellent electrocatalytic performance, which could be attributed to the following points: (i) the well-dispersive Pt nanoparticles with ultrafine sizes, provide a mass of active sites, benefit to raise the electrochemical activity; (ii) after intercalated by MWCNTs, Ti3C2T x possess larger layer spacing and surface area, provide high accessibility surface to Pt particles; (iii) MWCNTs act as conductive “bridge” among different blocks of Ti3C2T x , not only enhance the layer space of Ti3C2T x , also improve the electron transfer to a great speed. 4 Conclusions In summary, Ti3C2T x -MWCNTs supported ultrafine Pt nanoparticles were successfully fabricated by a facile solvothermal method. The microstructural investigation revealed that three components were successfully compounded together, in which MWCNTs has acted as a conductive “bridge” to connect Ti3C2T x blocks and provide more active sites. The outstanding electrocatalytic activity was achieved for Pt/(Ti3C2T x )0.5-(MWCNTs)0.5, whose electrochemical active surface area was 154 m2/g, and the forward peak current density reached 812.9 mA/mg for methanol electro-oxidation, and the CO-poisoning tolerance for methanol oxidation was superior to those Pt catalysts in literature. The present study presents a breakthrough in MXene-based materials to significantly prompt their rapid development and applications in fuel cells. coredata.dc:description: Although direct methanol fuel cells are promising as “green” power generators for portable electronics, their further development has been largely hampered by the low-efficiency of the commercial anode catalysts. In this study, (Ti3C2T x ) y -(MWCNTs)1- y (0 ≤ y ≤1) supported Pt nanoparticle electrocatalysts were fabricated by a facile and scalable solvothermal strategy, after which two-dimensional(2D) Ti3C2T x nanosheets were found to be intercalated and connected by conductive one-dimensional(1D) MWCNTs. Used for methanol oxidation reaction, the Pt/(Ti3C2T x )0.5-(MWCNTs)0.5 catalyst exhibited the maximum electrochemical active surface area (ECSA, 154 m2/g) and excellent electrochemical activity (812.9 mA/mg), higher than not only Pt/Ti3C2T x and Pt/MWCNTs of this study, but also many other related catalysts reported in literature. In addition, the CO-poisoning behavior was also alleviated using Pt/(Ti3C2T x )0.5-(MWCNTs)0.5 instead of Pt/Ti3C2T x and Pt/MWCNTs. Such a superior performance can be attributed to the well dispersion of Pt nanoparticles (∼3.8 nm), enhanced layer distance of Ti3C2T x to capture more Pt nanoparticles, and conductive action of MWCNTs to connect Ti3C2T x . This study opens a new perspective for developing high performance supercapacitors using Pt catalysts supported by 1D-intercalated 2D materials.
coredata.dc:title: Preparation of Pt/(Ti3C2T x ) y -(MWCNTs)1- y electrocatalysts via a facile and scalable solvothermal strategy for high-efficiency methanol oxidation
